awd_titl_txt: Developing Resilient STEM Teachers for High-Need Middle Schools
awd_abstract_narration:
Developing Resilient STEM Teachers for High-Need Middle Schools is a Track 1 Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship project. The project will address the national demand for qualified STEM teachers in Arizona. This shortage is a result of two primary factors: the lack of qualified candidates entering the profession and the retention of qualified candidates who become teachers and leave the profession within two years. This Track 1 Noyce project will address this shortage by implementing a mentorship program to guide the development of new teachers at Title I schools in two high-need districts in the Phoenix, AZ region. Arizona State University will support this project through: (1) preparing 24 new highly qualified teachers (with a bachelor's degree in a STEM field) to become a certified K - 8 teacher while earning a Master's degree; (2) retaining middle school mathematics and science teachers through a three-year induction program; and (3) training teachers in teaching practices that are known to support STEM career paths for underrepresented groups (minorities and women). As part of the project, Noyce Scholars will be prepared to use curriculum materials that incorporate state-of-the-art engineering practices.  Scholars will use these materials in engineering summer camps for middle school students and their families.

Developing Resilient STEM Teachers for High-Need Middle Schools will provide one-year Noyce stipends to two cohorts of 12 students. The project will produce 24 highly qualified mathematics and science middle school teachers who can positively impact students in high-need schools. As a form of teacher development, Noyce scholars will teach in an on-campus engineering summer camp. Additionally, the project will include a teacher induction mentorship program focused on improving teacher quality through professional development. Through placement of expert teachers in high-need districts, the project has the potential to positively affect more than 3,600 students each year after the grant concludes. Middle school students will benefit by receiving a quality education from teachers who are trained to be leaders in STEM. With a quality classroom experience, students will be more likely to pursue STEM courses as they progress into high school and to acquire the knowledge needed to thrive in STEM careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Developing Resilient STEM Teachers for High-Need Middle Schools (NSF Noyce Award #1758368) project aimed to increase the number of highly qualified STEM teachers, particularly in high-need schools. Over its duration, the initiative focused on recruiting and training new STEM educators, enhancing retention rates, and fostering the integration of project-based learning in STEM education.

Throughout the life of the award, three cohorts of teacher scholars were engaged in a rigorous certification and master’s degree program. Overall, the three cohorts yielded a completion rate of 75%, with 18 out of 24 scholars meeting the requirements of certification, degree completion, and two years of teaching in a high-need school or district. The 75% success rate suggests that the program's commitment to providing targeted training and mentorship can influence teacher retention and success. Six scholars did not complete program requirements: two scholars did not complete their certification and degree program; four scholars did not complete their two-year teaching obligation. The COVID-19 pandemic seemed to have negatively impacted the scholars who did not complete their teaching obligation.

Surveys and interviews conducted among scholars highlighted their perceptions of persistence in the teaching profession. While some expressed concerns about remaining in teaching, it is essential to recognize these feelings are common across the profession, especially within the first five years of entering the teaching profession. Our findings underscore the importance of ongoing support and professional development, which we are committed to providing.

 

Intellectual Merit

We integrated project-based learning into the STEM curriculum and equipped teachers with advanced training through a Master's degree program and professional development sessions. We aimed to enhance the pedagogical skills of highly qualified mathematics and science teachers ensuring that their students in high-need schools received consistent, high-quality instruction.

By preparing individuals who had already earned a bachelors degree in a STEM field to enter the teaching profession we aimed to increase the presence of educators with a STEM background in high-need middle-school classrooms. This foundational exposure is essential for cultivating a new generation of skilled professionals, ultimately contributing to a more diverse STEM workforce.

 

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of our grant extend far beyond the immediate objective of training highly qualified STEM teachers. By addressing the critical shortage of capable educators in high-need school districts, we aimed to transform the educational landscape for approximately 1,800 students annually. These students, who sometimes lack access to quality teachers, received high-quality instruction tailored to inspire and motivate them in STEM subjects. 

Data gathered at the end of the project showed that most teachers who remained in the classroom are likely to persist in the profession. They expressed fulfillment in teaching, emphasizing the rewarding nature of building relationships with students and contributing to their development. Some positive outcomes we identified from our thematic analysis of qualitative data from scholars who continued to persist in teaching included their passion for teaching, and professional growth as a result of teaching.

Some teachers noted challenges such as classroom management and workload. Specifically, teachers mentioned that they felt underpaid or overwhelmed by additional responsibilities outside of teaching. A few noted that teaching students how to manage their behavior in addition to teaching content knowledge indicated a misalignment in their STEM skills and their assigned responsibilities.

Despite these challenges, scholars identified the role of mentorship provided by school administrators, coaches fellow teachers, and wellness department personnel that helped them persist. Scholars noted that the financial support received from the Noyce project were significant factors in their desire to enter and persist in the teaching profession. Financial support included scholarships to earn their teaching certification and graduate degree, and salary supplements.

Several scholars noted the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their teacher preparation experiences and their first-year of teaching. These challenges included the need to adapt to remote teaching and learning, difficulties connecting with students, and the ensuing disruption to traditional classroom practices. This was an important contributing factor for some scholars who did not complete their two-years of teaching requirements in a high-need school.

 


Last Modified: 01/22/2025
Modified by: Tirupalavanam G Ganesh
